paragraphs.text:
%md

##Tutorial using Apache Spark with the PySpark API
###Introduction
To run a paragraph in a Zeppelin notebook you can either click the `play` button (blue triangle) on the right-hand side or simply press `Shift + Enter`.

This tutorial is in Spark Python (PySpark). PySpark must be invoked in each cell that we wish to run Python code in by adding `%pyspark` to the beginning of a cell. Cells with text like this one are in Markdown, which is invoked by `%md`. If an interpreter is not called in a cell, then it uses the default Spark (Scala).

**Reminder:** In Zeppelin, SparkContext, SQLContext, and ZeppelinContext are automically created and exposed as variable names 'sc', 'sqlContext' and 'z' in both scala and python environments. Outside of Zeppelin, these would have to be created by you.

result.msg:
Tutorial using Apache Spark with the PySpark API

Introduction

To run a paragraph in a Zeppelin notebook you can either click the play button (blue triangle) on the right-hand side or simply press Shift + Enter.

This tutorial is in Spark Python (PySpark). PySpark must be invoked in each cell that we wish to run Python code in by adding %pyspark to the beginning of a cell. Cells with text like this one are in Markdown, which is invoked by %md. If an interpreter is not called in a cell, then it uses the default Spark (Scala).

Reminder: In Zeppelin, SparkContext, SQLContext, and ZeppelinContext are automically created and exposed as variable names 'sc', 'sqlContext' and 'z' in both scala and python environments. Outside of Zeppelin, these would have to be created by you.

paragraphs.text:
%md

###Transformations and Actions
All operations are either transformations or actions
**Transformation** operations are applied to a RDD/DataFrame to create a new RDD/DataFrame.
**Action** operations initiate a computation and returns the result back to the driver program
Transformations use lazy evaluation meaning the code will not execute until there is an action. This can make debugging difficult because you could have an issue in your code and not get an error when running until an action is used.

Transformations covered in this tutorial:
- filter()
- orderBy()
- distinct()
- dropDuplicates()
- select()
- drop()
- withColumn()
- withColumnRenamed()
- groupBy()

Actions covered in this tutorial:
- show()
- collect()
- count()


**Note:** For reference, the details of these methods along with many others not covered in this tutorial can be found in the Apache Spark's PySpark [documentation](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/api/python/pyspark.sql.html#pyspark-sql-module). This link takes you to the latest version of Spark, but there are notes for each method that show what version it was released in or if it was changed in a particular version.

result.msg:
Transformations and Actions

All operations are either transformations or actions
Transformation operations are applied to a RDD/DataFrame to create a new RDD/DataFrame.
Action operations initiate a computation and returns the result back to the driver program
Transformations use lazy evaluation meaning the code will not execute until there is an action. This can make debugging difficult because you could have an issue in your code and not get an error when running until an action is used.

Transformations covered in this tutorial:

  • filter()
  • orderBy()
  • distinct()
  • dropDuplicates()
  • select()
  • drop()
  • withColumn()
  • withColumnRenamed()
  • groupBy()

Actions covered in this tutorial:

  • show()
  • collect()
  • count()

Note: For reference, the details of these methods along with many others not covered in this tutorial can be found in the Apache Spark's PySpark documentation. This link takes you to the latest version of Spark, but there are notes for each method that show what version it was released in or if it was changed in a particular version.

paragraphs.text:
%md

###Library Import

Python libraries (packages) can be imported in same way as in Python using an `import` statement. Anaconda is also configured for this environment so all of these packages are available as well. 
*Note for if you're working in a different environment: If using Anaconda packages, it is important to ensure it has been installed and configured on every node in the cluster.*

result.msg:
Library Import

Python libraries (packages) can be imported in same way as in Python using an import statement. Anaconda is also configured for this environment so all of these packages are available as well.
Note for if you're working in a different environment: If using Anaconda packages, it is important to ensure it has been installed and configured on every node in the cluster.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Import the datetime library
import datetime
print 'This was last run on: {0}'.format(datetime.datetime.now())

%pyspark

# There are several things that may need to be imported in PySpark. These will be specific to your data analysis. Best practice is to keep all these statements at the top of your code. 
# This is only for reference...run for this cell has been disabled.

# Here are just a few examples:
from pyspark.sql.functions import udf, abs, toRadians, lag, lead, first, lit, round
from pyspark.sql.types.import StringType
from pyspark.sql import Row, functions as F
from pyspark.sql.window import Window

%md

### Creating and working with DataFrames 

First, we will create a basic DataFrame with an array of data

result.msg:
Creating and working with DataFrames

First, we will create a basic DataFrame with an array of data

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df = sqlContext.createDataFrame([("Roberto", 58, "Professor", "Nevada", 714), 
                                 ("Zoe", 25, "Lawyer", "California", 811), 
                                 ("Robin", 30, "Reporter", "California", 639), 
                                 ("Edward", 72, "Retired", "Florida", 790), 
                                 ("Jack", 16, "Student", "California", None), 
                                 ("Zoe", 25, "Lawyer", "California", 811), 
                                 ("Jack", 23, "Bartender", "Nevada", 564)], 
                                 ("name", "age", "occupation", "state", "credit_score"))

%md

We can check the type `sql.Context.createDataFrame()` to see what it returned

result.msg: We can check the type sql.Context.createDataFrame() to see what it returned

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

print 'type of df: {0}'.format(type(df))

result.msg: type of df: <class 'pyspark.sql.dataframe.DataFrame'>

paragraphs.text:
%md

DataFrames require a schema, which is a list of columns. The column types will be inferred from the data. If schema is None it will try to infer the schema (column names and types) from the data.

`createDataFrame(data, schema)`

result.msg:
DataFrames require a schema, which is a list of columns. The column types will be inferred from the data. If schema is None it will try to infer the schema (column names and types) from the data.

createDataFrame(data, schema)

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.printSchema()

result.msg:
root
 |-- name: string (nullable = true)
 |-- age: long (nullable = true)
 |-- occupation: string (nullable = true)
 |-- state: string (nullable = true)
 |-- credit_score: long (nullable = true)

paragraphs.text:
%md

**dtypes** is another way to look at column names and their data type. This returns a list.

result.msg: dtypes is another way to look at column names and their data type. This returns a list.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

print df.dtypes

result.msg: [('name', 'string'), ('age', 'bigint'), ('occupation', 'string'), ('state', 'string'), ('credit_score', 'bigint')]

paragraphs.text:
%md
###Use **show** to view the results
`show()` prints the first n rows. Default: n=20, truncate=True. These parameters can be changed, example: 
    df.show(2, truncate=False)

result.msg:
Use show to view the results

show() prints the first n rows. Default: n=20, truncate=True. These parameters can be changed, example:

df.show(2, truncate=False)

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
|   name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
|Roberto| 58| Professor|    Nevada|         714|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
|  Robin| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|
| Edward| 72|   Retired|   Florida|         790|
|   Jack| 16|   Student|California|        null|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
|   Jack| 23| Bartender|    Nevada|         564|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md
### **Collect** 
`collect()` is another way to display the DataFrame by gathering the entries from all partitions into the driver. 
WARNING: The data returned to the driver must fit into the driver's available memory. If not, the driver will crash. This is only to be used if returned a small amount of data to the driver. `show()` is a better way to visualize the data and not worry about memory.

result.msg:
Collect

collect() is another way to display the DataFrame by gathering the entries from all partitions into the driver.
WARNING: The data returned to the driver must fit into the driver's available memory. If not, the driver will crash. This is only to be used if returned a small amount of data to the driver. show() is a better way to visualize the data and not worry about memory.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

results = df.collect()
print results

result.msg: [Row(name=u'Roberto', age=58, occupation=u'Professor', state=u'Nevada', credit_score=714), Row(name=u'Zoe', age=25, occupation=u'Lawyer', state=u'California', credit_score=811), Row(name=u'Robin', age=30, occupation=u'Reporter', state=u'California', credit_score=639), Row(name=u'Edward', age=72, occupation=u'Retired', state=u'Florida', credit_score=790), Row(name=u'Jack', age=16, occupation=u'Student', state=u'California', credit_score=None), Row(name=u'Zoe', age=25, occupation=u'Lawyer', state=u'California', credit_score=811), Row(name=u'Jack', age=23, occupation=u'Bartender', state=u'Nevada', credit_score=564)]

paragraphs.text:
%md

How many partitions will the DataFrame be split into? 
*Since this is a local instance of Spark there is only 1 node, therefore there will only be 1 partition*

result.msg:
How many partitions will the DataFrame be split into?
Since this is a local instance of Spark there is only 1 node, therefore there will only be 1 partition

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

print df.rdd.getNumPartitions()

%md

### **count** total number of rows
`count()` returns the number of rows in this DataFrame. It is also an action operation.

result.msg:
count total number of rows

count() returns the number of rows in this DataFrame. It is also an action operation.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

print df.count()

%md ### Notes on syntax We can write any of these examples to create a new DataFrame if we wanted to keep the resulting DataFrame, which is typically what you would do in data processing. However, since these are just for learning, I'm going to just add a `show()` to the end of each. This does not overwrite the DataFrame since DataFrames are immutable. For example, to create a new DataFrame filtered_df = df.filter(df.age < 32) filtered_df.show() To simply view results of a transformation df.filter(df.age < 32).show()
#### Referencing Columns There are a few different ways to refer to columns in PySpark Using Strings to refer to columns df.sort("age") Using a `column` object, there are two different notations: #Pandas style notation df.sort(df.age) #subscript notation df.sort(df['age']) Using the `col` function with the column name as a string. Must first import `col`. from pyspark.sql.functions import col df.sort(col("age"))

result.msg:
Notes on syntax

We can write any of these examples to create a new DataFrame if we wanted to keep the resulting DataFrame, which is typically what you would do in data processing. However, since these are just for learning, I'm going to just add a show() to the end of each.
This does not overwrite the DataFrame since DataFrames are immutable.

For example, to create a new DataFrame

filtered_df = df.filter(df.age < 32)
filtered_df.show()

To simply view results of a transformation

df.filter(df.age < 32).show()


Referencing Columns

There are a few different ways to refer to columns in PySpark

Using Strings to refer to columns

df.sort("age")

Using a column object, there are two different notations:

#Pandas style notation
df.sort(df.age)

#subscript notation
df.sort(df['age'])

Using the col function with the column name as a string. Must first import col.

from pyspark.sql.functions import col
df.sort(col("age"))

paragraphs.text:
%md

###**filter**

`filter()` transformation filters rows using the given condition. **where()** is an alias for **filter()**

result.msg:
filter

filter() transformation filters rows using the given condition. where() is an alias for filter()

paragraphs.text:
%md

Keep only records that contain people whose age is less than 32.

result.msg: Keep only records that contain people whose age is less than 32.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.filter(df.age < 32).show()

result.msg:
+-----+---+----------+----------+------------+
| name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|
+-----+---+----------+----------+------------+
|  Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
|Robin| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|
| Jack| 16|   Student|California|        null|
|  Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
| Jack| 23| Bartender|    Nevada|         564|
+-----+---+----------+----------+------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

###**orderBy**
`orderBy()` allows you to sort a DataFrame by one or more columns. `sort()` is an alias of `orderBy()`.

result.msg:
orderBy

orderBy() allows you to sort a DataFrame by one or more columns. sort() is an alias of orderBy().

paragraphs.text:
%md

Let's sort names alphabetically

result.msg: Let's sort names alphabetically

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.orderBy(df.name).show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
|   name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
| Edward| 72|   Retired|   Florida|         790|
|   Jack| 16|   Student|California|        null|
|   Jack| 23| Bartender|    Nevada|         564|
|Roberto| 58| Professor|    Nevada|         714|
|  Robin| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md 

Now sort by oldest to youngest using the method `desc` (for sorting in descending order). The method `asc()` is the default (for sorting in ascending order)

result.msg: Now sort by oldest to youngest using the method desc (for sorting in descending order). The method asc() is the default (for sorting in ascending order)

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.orderBy(df.age.desc()).show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
|   name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
| Edward| 72|   Retired|   Florida|         790|
|Roberto| 58| Professor|    Nevada|         714|
|  Robin| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
|   Jack| 23| Bartender|    Nevada|         564|
|   Jack| 16|   Student|California|        null|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

Since ascending is the default, it will work by using either the string or column expression.

    df.orderBy('age')
    #or
    df.orderBy(df.age)

The `desc()` method is already defined for `column` objects, however, it is not for string objects.

For example, this would not work
    df.orderBy('age'.desc())

If you really wanted to write it that way you would have to import the `desc` method

    # Import needed functions
    from pyspark.sql.functions import desc
    df.orderBy("name", desc("score"))

result.msg:
Since ascending is the default, it will work by using either the string or column expression.

df.orderBy('age')
#or
df.orderBy(df.age)

The desc() method is already defined for column objects, however, it is not for string objects.

For example, this would not work

df.orderBy('age'.desc())

If you really wanted to write it that way you would have to import the desc method

# Import needed functions
from pyspark.sql.functions import desc
df.orderBy("name", desc("score"))

paragraphs.text:
%md

### **distinct()** and **dropDuplicates()**

result.msg: distinct() and dropDuplicates()

paragraphs.text:
%md 

`distinct()` considers all columns and filters out duplicate rows to return a DataFrame with only unique rows.

result.msg: distinct() filters out duplicate rows and considers all columns.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.distinct().show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
|   name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
|   Jack| 16|   Student|California|        null|
|Roberto| 58| Professor|    Nevada|         714|
|   Jack| 23| Bartender|    Nevada|         564|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
|  Robin| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|
| Edward| 72|   Retired|   Florida|         790|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

One of the rows with Zoe was deleted, but the two rows with name "Jack" are kept because the other columns for these two rows are different and all columns in a row must match another row for it to be considered a duplicate.

result.msg: One of the rows with Zoe was deleted, but the two rows with name “Jack” are kept because the other columns for these two rows are different and all columns in a row must match another row for it to be considered a duplicate.

paragraphs.text:
%md

`dropDuplicates()` is similar to `distinct()`, except it has the option to consider only certain columns. Let's only drop rows if they have the duplicate names.

result.msg: dropDuplicates() is similar to distinct(), except it has the option to consider only certain columns. Let's only drop rows if they have the duplicate names.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.dropDuplicates(['name']).show()

%md

Notice this drops one row for "Zoe" and one for "Jack". It kept the first row with "Jack" and drops the other. It's important to use a sort if you want more control over which rows are discarded. Let's sort by age so that the older Jack will be kept.

result.msg: Notice this drops one row for “Zoe” and one for “Jack”. It kept the first row with “Jack” and drops the other. It's important to use a sort if you want more control over which rows are discarded. Let's sort by age so that the older Jack will be kept.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.sort(df.name, df.age).dropDuplicates(['name']).show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
|   name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
|   Jack| 16|   Student|California|        null|
| Edward| 72|   Retired|   Florida|         790|
|  Robin| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|
|Roberto| 58| Professor|    Nevada|         714|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

###**select()** and **drop()**

`select()` and `drop()` are opposites of each other. We can either select specific columns we want to keep or drop a specified column from a DataFrame. Decide which would require less work, for example if you have 100 columns and you want to get rid of 5 columns then it's easier to drop those 5 than to select the 95 you want to keep.

result.msg:
select() and drop()

select() and drop() are opposites of each other. We can either select specific columns we want to keep or drop a specified column from a DataFrame. Decide which would require less work, for example if you have 100 columns and you want to get rid of 5 columns then it's easier to drop those 5 than to select the 95 you want to keep.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.select("name", "age").show()

%pyspark

df.drop("credit_score").drop("occupation").show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+
|   name|age|     state|
+-------+---+----------+
|Roberto| 58|    Nevada|
|    Zoe| 25|California|
|  Robin| 30|California|
| Edward| 72|   Florida|
|   Jack| 16|California|
|    Zoe| 25|California|
|   Jack| 23|    Nevada|
+-------+---+----------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

Notice in `drop()` you can only have one column per `drop()`, so if you want to drop multiple columns you have to use multiple `drop()`

result.msg: Notice in drop() you can only have one column per drop(), so if you want to drop multiple columns you have to use multiple drop()

paragraphs.text:
%md

###Use **withColumn** to create a new column

To start simple, let's create a new age variable that is a person's age plus 1

result.msg:
Use withColumn to create a new column

To start simple, let's create a new age variable that is a person's age plus 1

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.withColumn("new_age", df.age + 1).show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+-------+
|   name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|new_age|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+-------+
|Roberto| 58| Professor|    Nevada|         714|     59|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|     26|
|  Robin| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|     31|
| Edward| 72|   Retired|   Florida|         790|     73|
|   Jack| 16|   Student|California|        null|     17|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|     26|
|   Jack| 23| Bartender|    Nevada|         564|     24|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+-------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

Next, let's convert the column 'name' to uppercase. In this example, rather than creating a new column we overwrite the 'name' column with the new values

result.msg: Next, let's convert the column 'name' to uppercase. In this example, rather than creating a new column we overwrite the 'name' column with the new values

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql.functions import upper

df.withColumn("name", upper(df.name)).show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
|   name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+
|ROBERTO| 58| Professor|    Nevada|         714|
|    ZOE| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
|  ROBIN| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|
| EDWARD| 72|   Retired|   Florida|         790|
|   JACK| 16|   Student|California|        null|
|    ZOE| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|
|   JACK| 23| Bartender|    Nevada|         564|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

We can also create a new column with conditional values. Let's specify if a person is an adult or child by their age.

result.msg: We can also create a new column with conditional values. Let's specify if a person is an adult or child by their age.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql.functions import when

df.withColumn("age_category", when(df.age < 18, "minor").otherwise("adult")).show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+------------+
|   name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|age_category|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+------------+
|Roberto| 58| Professor|    Nevada|         714|       adult|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|       adult|
|  Robin| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|       adult|
| Edward| 72|   Retired|   Florida|         790|       adult|
|   Jack| 16|   Student|California|        null|       minor|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|       adult|
|   Jack| 23| Bartender|    Nevada|         564|       adult|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

All of the examples above create a new column by using an existing column. You can add an arbitary column by using literals: `lit()`

Let's add a new column called 'country' to our DataFrame and set all values to USA.

result.msg:
All of the examples above create a new column by using an existing column. You can add an arbitary column by using literals: lit()

Let's add a new column called 'country' to our DataFrame and set all values to USA.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql.functions import lit

df.withColumn("country", lit("USA")).show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+-------+
|   name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|country|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+-------+
|Roberto| 58| Professor|    Nevada|         714|    USA|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|    USA|
|  Robin| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|    USA|
| Edward| 72|   Retired|   Florida|         790|    USA|
|   Jack| 16|   Student|California|        null|    USA|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|    USA|
|   Jack| 23| Bartender|    Nevada|         564|    USA|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+-------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

We can do the same if we want to add a constant column with an integer.

result.msg: We can do the same if we want to add a constant column with an integer.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.withColumn("x", lit(0)).show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+---+
|   name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|  x|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+---+
|Roberto| 58| Professor|    Nevada|         714|  0|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|  0|
|  Robin| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|  0|
| Edward| 72|   Retired|   Florida|         790|  0|
|   Jack| 16|   Student|California|        null|  0|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|  0|
|   Jack| 23| Bartender|    Nevada|         564|  0|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+---+

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Rename columns using **withColumnRenamed**

`withColumnRenamed(existing, new)`

result.msg:
Rename columns using withColumnRenamed

withColumnRenamed(existing, new)

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.withColumnRenamed("occupation", "job").show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+---------+----------+------------+
|   name|age|      job|     state|credit_score|
+-------+---+---------+----------+------------+
|Roberto| 58|Professor|    Nevada|         714|
|    Zoe| 25|   Lawyer|California|         811|
|  Robin| 30| Reporter|California|         639|
| Edward| 72|  Retired|   Florida|         790|
|   Jack| 16|  Student|California|        null|
|    Zoe| 25|   Lawyer|California|         811|
|   Jack| 23|Bartender|    Nevada|         564|
+-------+---+---------+----------+------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

### **groupBy**

`groupBy()` groups the DataFrame by the specified columns in order to do aggregations. Note `groupby()` is an alias for `groupBy()`. The aggregation functions typically create a new column. There are many different aggregation functions, the most common is `count()`, and a few others are `sum()`, `avg()`, `max()`, `min()`

First, count records by 'state'

result.msg:
groupBy

groupBy() groups the DataFrame by the specified columns in order to do aggregations. Note groupby() is an alias for groupBy(). The aggregation functions typically create a new column. There are many different aggregation functions, the most common is count(), and a few others are sum(), avg(), max(), min()

First, count records by 'state'

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.groupBy("state").count().show()

%md

Next, let's find out the age of the youngest person in each state.

result.msg: Next, let's find out the age of the youngest person in each state.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df.groupby("state").min("age").show()

%md 

### Replacing null values with **fillna**

`fillna(value, subset=None)`: the value parameter is the value to replace the null values with and subset is an optinal list of column names to apply this to. Alias for `na.fill()`.

Let's create a DataFrame with some missing data

result.msg:
Replacing null values with fillna

fillna(value, subset=None): the value parameter is the value to replace the null values with and subset is an optinal list of column names to apply this to. Alias for na.fill().

Let's create a DataFrame with some missing data

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

missing_df = sqlContext.createDataFrame([(2, 1), (6, None), (None, 4)], ("x", "y"))
                                 
missing_df.show()

%md

In the first example below, all missing values in the DataFrame are filled with zeros.

In the second example, we specify which column to fill.

result.msg:
In the first example below, all missing values in the DataFrame are filled with zeros.

In the second example, we specify which column to fill.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

missing_df.fillna(0).show()

%pyspark

missing_df.fillna(0, "y").show()

%md 

###Merging muliptle DataFrames using **join()**
`join(other, on=None, how=None)`

Parameters: 
 - other  Right side of the join
 - on  a string for join column name or a list of column names. If on is a string or a list of string indicating the name of the join column(s), the column(s) must exist on both sides, and this performs an equi-join.
 - how  default inner. Options: inner, outer, left_outer, right_outer, leftsemi.

result.msg:
Merging muliptle DataFrames using join()

join(other, on=None, how=None)

Parameters:

  • other Right side of the join
  • on a string for join column name or a list of column names. If on is a string or a list of string indicating the name of the join column(s), the column(s) must exist on both sides, and this performs an equi-join.
  • how default inner. Options: inner, outer, left_outer, right_outer, leftsemi.

paragraphs.text:
%md

Let's create two new DataFrames to demonstrate joins.

result.msg: Let's create two new DataFrames to demonstrate joins.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark 

df1 = sqlContext.createDataFrame([("Emma", 24, "S"), ("Sophia", 53, "M"), ("Jacob", 35, "M"), ("Adam", 38, "S")], ("name", "age", "marital_stat"))
                                 
df2 = sqlContext.createDataFrame([("Emma", "Dallas"), ("Sophia", "San Francisco"), ("Adam", "Orlando"), ("William", "San Diego")], ("name", "city"))

df1.show()
df2.show()

%md

Now let's do an inner join on these two DataFrames by "name" to only keep rows that match between the column in both DataFrames.

result.msg: Now let's do an inner join on these two DataFrames by “name” to only keep rows that match between the column in both DataFrames.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df1.join(df2, "name", "inner").show()

%md

Since Jacob was not in the second DataFrame and William was not in the first DataFrame, these two records are not included in the new DataFrame.

Let's do an outer join to keep all records from both DataFrames.

result.msg:
Since Jacob was not in the second DataFrame and William was not in the first DataFrame, these two records are not included in the new DataFrame.

Let's do an outer join to keep all records from both DataFrames.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

df1.join(df2, "name", "outer").show()

%md

### Using **unionAll()** to append DataFrames

The two DataFrames must contain the same number of columns and the corresponding columns must have compatible data types. Column names are only considered in the first DataFrame and ignored else where, which means it's extrememly important for the columns in both DataFrames be in the same exact order. If not, the `unionAll()` will return wrong results.

Let's create a new DataFrame with names and cities, and then use `unionAll()` with the previous DataFrame we created with names and cities.

result.msg:
Using unionAll() to append DataFrames

The two DataFrames must contain the same number of columns and the corresponding columns must have compatible data types. Column names are only considered in the first DataFrame and ignored else where, which means it's extrememly important for the columns in both DataFrames be in the same exact order. If not, the unionAll() will return wrong results.

Let's create a new DataFrame with names and cities, and then use unionAll() with the previous DataFrame we created with names and cities.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Create a new DataFrame
df3 = sqlContext.createDataFrame([("Luke", "Raleigh"), ("Peter", "New York")], ("name", "city"))
df3.show()

# Previous DataFrame
df2.show()

df2.unionAll(df3).show()

result.msg:
+-----+--------+
| name|    city|
+-----+--------+
| Luke| Raleigh|
|Peter|New York|
+-----+--------+

+-------+-------------+
|   name|         city|
+-------+-------------+
|   Emma|       Dallas|
| Sophia|San Francisco|
|   Adam|      Orlando|
|William|    San Diego|
+-------+-------------+

+-------+-------------+
|   name|         city|
+-------+-------------+
|   Emma|       Dallas|
| Sophia|San Francisco|
|   Adam|      Orlando|
|William|    San Diego|
|   Luke|      Raleigh|
|  Peter|     New York|
+-------+-------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

What if in our new DataFrame the column order was different?

result.msg: What if in our new DataFrame the column order was different?

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Reordering columns in df3
df3 = df3.select("city", "name")

# Check columns
print df3.columns
print df2.columns

df2.unionAll(df3).show()

result.msg:
['city', 'name']
['name', 'city']
+--------+-------------+
|    name|         city|
+--------+-------------+
|    Emma|       Dallas|
|  Sophia|San Francisco|
|    Adam|      Orlando|
| William|    San Diego|
| Raleigh|         Luke|
|New York|        Peter|
+--------+-------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

The union is still performed without error because both DataFrames have two columns with the same data types, but the results are clearly wrong. As demonstrated in the code above, you can use `df.columns` to print the column names and order in a DataFrame. You can use this to ensure the columns are in the same order before doing a union. Also, as seen above, you can easily change the order by using `select()` and inputting the columns in the order you desire.

result.msg: The union is still performed without error because both DataFrames have two columns with the same data types, but the results are clearly wrong. As demonstrated in the code above, you can use df.columns to print the column names and order in a DataFrame. You can use this to ensure the column are in the same order before doing a union. Also as seen above, you can easily change the order by using select() and inputting the columns in the order you desire.

paragraphs.text:
%md

###**Lambda Functions** and **User Defined Functions**

Python supports a special syntax for building one-line anonymous functions. Lambda functions can be used wherever function objects are required. Lambda functions can take only a single expression. Using lambda functions is not ever required and you can always define a normal function instead, but in certain cases lambda functions can be more convenient and make writing code easier and cleaner. These can be used in situations where you need to create a function that is only going to be used once.

In Spark, a UDF (User Defined Function) is a special wrapper that allows you to use a feature that is not available in Spark by default.

result.msg:
Lambda Functions and User Defined Functions

Python supports a special syntax for building one-line anonymous functions. Lambda functions can be used wherever function objects are required. Lambda functions can take only a single expression. Using lambda functions is not ever required and you can always define a normal function instead, but in certain cases lambda functions can be more convenient and make writing code easier and cleaner. These can be used in situations where you need to create a function that is only going to be used once.

In Spark, a UDF (User Defined Function) is a special wrapper that allows you to use a feature that is not available in Spark by default.

paragraphs.text:
%md

Using out initial DataFrame, let's find the birth year of each person by substracting their age from the year 2016. There are many ways we can do this, but let's use a Lambda function and UDF to demonstate the concepts just introduced.

result.msg: Using out initial DataFrame, let's find the birth year of each person by substracting their age from the year 2016. There are many ways we can do this, but let's use a Lambda function and UDF to demonstate the concepts just introduced.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql.functions import udf
from pyspark.sql.types import StringType

birth_year = udf(lambda x: (2016 - x), StringType())

lambda_df1 = df.withColumn('birth_year', birth_year(df.age))

lambda_df1.show()

%md

We can also apply a UDF to a Python defined function. Using our second DataFrame with scores, let's define a function to determines a person's letter grade.

result.msg: We can also apply a UDF to a Python defined function. Let's use our second DataFrame with scores and define a function to determines a person's letter grade.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

def credit_category(credit_score):
    if credit_score > 800: return 'Excellent'
    elif credit_score > 740: return 'Very Good'
    elif credit_score > 670: return 'Good'
    elif credit_score > 580: return 'Fair'
    elif credit_score > 300: return 'Poor'
    else: return ' '
    
credit_category_udf = udf(credit_category, StringType())

df_new = df.withColumn("grade", credit_category_udf(df.credit_score))

df_new.show()

result.msg:
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+---------+
|   name|age|occupation|     state|credit_score|    grade|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+---------+
|Roberto| 58| Professor|    Nevada|         714|     Good|
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|Excellent|
|  Robin| 30|  Reporter|California|         639|     Fair|
| Edward| 72|   Retired|   Florida|         790|Very Good|
|   Jack| 16|   Student|California|        null|         |
|    Zoe| 25|    Lawyer|California|         811|Excellent|
|   Jack| 23| Bartender|    Nevada|         564|     Poor|
+-------+---+----------+----------+------------+---------+

paragraphs.text:
%md

###Good Programming Practices

As you began to program in Spark, the recommended way to write code is in the form:

    df2 = df1.transformation1()
    df2.action1()
    df3 = df2.transformation2()
    df3.action2()
    
Coding in this style will make debugging easier.

As you gain experience you can condense your code with the form:

    df.transformation1().transformation2().action()
    
Try to keep your coding style readable. The above example can become messy if you add multiple operations on one line. 
You can enclose the statement in parentheses and put each method, transformation, and action on a separate line (demonstrated below).

result.msg:
Good Programming Practices

As you began to program in Spark, the recommended way to write code is in the form:

df2 = df1.transformation1()
df2.action1()
df3 = df2.transformation2()
df3.action2()

Coding in this style will make debugging easier.

As you gain experience you can condense your code with the form:

df.transformation1().transformation2().action()

Try to keep your coding style readable. The above example can become messy if you add multiple operations on one line.
You can enclose the statement in parentheses and put each method, transformation, and action on a separate line (demonstrated below).

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql.functions import concat, lit

(df
  .filter(df.age > 18)
  .select(df.name, df.occupation, df.age)
  .withColumn("age_range", concat((df.age/10).cast("int") * 10, lit("-"), ((df.age/10).cast("int") + 1) * 10))
  .orderBy(df.name)
  .show()
  )

%md

##End of tutorial

result.msg: End of tutorial
